qas.question: What value system do Western scholars tend to use in analyzing societies?
Who does most of the gathering in a hunter-gatherer society?
What group members are the big game hunters?
What does the argument over women as gathers said to produce ?
How is childcare viewed in a hunter-gatherer society?
What gave the Neanderthals the edge over Homo sapiens?
It is easy to view what arrangements in the light of Eastern values?
One rare arrangement is the sexual division of what?
Every baby had one mother and one male carer in what society?

plausible_answers.text: the fundamental organisational innovation that gave Homo sapiens the edge over the Neanderthals

qas.question: Ancient archaeological research suggests that the sexual division of labor was what?

context: It is easy for Western-educated scholars to fall into the trap of viewing <b8_0>hunter-gatherer<b8_0/> <b6_0>social and sexual<b6_0/> arrange<a2_0>men<a2_0/>ts in the light of <a0_0>Western values<a0_0/>.[editorializing] One common arrangement is the sexual division of <b7_0>labour<b7_0/>, with <a1_0>women<a1_0/> doing most of the gathering, while men concentrate on big game hunting. It might be imagined that this <a3_0>arrangement oppresses women<a3_0/>, keeping them in the domestic sphere. However, according to some observers, hunter-gatherer women would not understand this interpretation. Since <a4_0>childcare is collective<a4_0/>, with every baby having multiple mothers and male carers, the domestic sphere is not atomised or privatised but an empowering place to be.[citation needed] In all hunter-gatherer societies, women appreciate the meat brought back to camp by men. An illustrative account is Megan Biesele's study of the southern African Ju/'hoan, 'Women Like Meat'. Recent archaeological research suggests that <b5_0>the sexual division of labor<b5_0/> was <b9_0>the fundamental organisational innovation that gave Homo sapiens the edge over the Neanderthals<b9_0/>, allowing our ancestors to migrate from Africa and spread across the globe.
